original: Subhasutta

translated: With Subha

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ānando sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme aciraparinibbute bhagavati.
analyzed: ekam samayam āyasmai ānandaḥ sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme acira parinibbute bhagavati
translated: Once the Venerable Ānanda was staying at Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park, not long after the Blessed One had attained final Nibbāna.

original: Tena kho pana samayena subho māṇavo todeyyaputto sāvatthiyaṁ paṭivasati kenacideva karaṇīyena.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya putto sāvatthiyam paṭivasati kenacid eva karaṇīyena
translated: At that time the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, was staying at Sāvatthī for some business or other.

original: Atha kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto aññataraṁ māṇavakaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha kho subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya puttaḥ aññataram māṇavakam āmantesi
translated: Then the brahmin student Subha approached a certain brahmin student and said to him:

original: “ehi tvaṁ, māṇavaka, yena samaṇo ānando tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena samaṇaṁ ānandaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ puccha:
analyzed: ehi tva māṇavaka yena samaṇaḥ ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkama upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena samaṇam ānandam appa ābādham appa ātaṅkam lahu ṭṭhānam balam phāsu vihāram puccha
translated: “Come, my dear, go to the ascetic Ānanda and ask in my name whether the ascetic Ānanda is free from illness and affliction, and is healthy, strong, and abiding in comfort, saying:

original: ‘subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṁ ānandaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchatī’ti.
analyzed: subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya puttaḥ bhavantam ānandam appa ābādham appa ātaṅkam lahu ṭṭhānam balam phāsu vihāram pucchati iti
translated: ‘Master Ānanda, the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, asks whether you are free from illness and affliction, and are healthy, strong, and abiding in comfort.’

original: Evañca vadehi:
analyzed: evañca vadehi
translated: And say this:

original: ‘sādhu kira bhavaṁ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṁ upādāyā’”ti.
analyzed: sādhu kira bhavam ānandaḥ yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyya puttassa nivesanam tena upasaṅkamatu anukampam upādāya ati
translated: ‘Please visit the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, out of compassion.’

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho so māṇavako subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho saḥ māṇavakaḥ subhassa māṇavassa todeyya puttassa paṭissutvā yena āyasmā ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhim sammodi
translated: “Yes, sir,” he replied, and he went to the venerable Ānanda and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so māṇavako āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ māṇavakaḥ āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: When this courteous and amiable talk was finished, he sat down at one side and said to the venerable Ānanda:

original: “subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṁ ānandaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchati;🔽evañca vadeti:
analyzed: subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya puttaḥ bhavantam ānandam appa ābādham appa ātaṅkam lahu ṭṭhānam balam phāsu vihāram pucchati  evañca vada iti
translated: “The brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, asks whether the venerable Ānanda is free from illness and affliction, and is flexible, strong, and abiding in comfort, saying:

original: ‘sādhu kira bhavaṁ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṁ upādāyā’”ti.
analyzed: sādhu kira bhavam ānandaḥ yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyya puttassa nivesanam tena upasaṅkamatu anukampam upādāya ati
translated: ‘It would be good if the venerable Ānanda would visit the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, out of compassion.’“

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando taṁ māṇavakaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmai ānandaḥ tam māṇavakam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the venerable Ānanda told him:

original: “akālo kho, māṇavaka.
analyzed: akālaḥ kho māṇavaka
translated: “It’s not the right time, student.

original: Atthi me ajja bhesajjamattā pītā.
analyzed: atthi me ajja bhesajja mattā pītā
translated: I’ve already taken my medicine for today.

original: Appevanāma svepi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāyā”ti.
analyzed: sve pi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāya ati
translated: Perhaps we can visit tomorrow, if it’s convenient for you.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho so māṇavako āyasmato ānandassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena subho māṇavo todeyyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā subhaṁ māṇavaṁ todeyyaputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: eva bhoti kho saḥ māṇavakaḥ āyasmataḥ ānandassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāya āsanā yena subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya putto tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā subham māṇavam todeyya puttam etat avoca
translated: “Yes, sir,” he replied. He then got up from his seat, went to Subha, and said to him,

analyzed: avocumha khalu mayam bhotaḥ vacanena tam bhavantam ānanda  subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya puttaḥ bhavantam ānandam appa ābādham appa ātaṅkam lahu ṭṭhānam balam phāsu vihāram pucchati evam ca vadeti  sādhu kira bhavam ānandaḥ yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyya puttassa nivesanam tena upasaṅkamatu anukampam upādāya ati
translated: “I told Master Ānanda what you said,

analyzed: evam vutte bho samaṇaḥ ānandaḥ mam etat avoca
translated: and he said this to me:

original: ‘akālo kho, māṇavaka.
analyzed: akālaḥ kho māṇavaka
translated: ‘It’s not the right time, student.

original: Atthi me ajja bhesajjamattā pītā.
analyzed: atthi me ajja bhesajja mattā pītā
translated: I’ve already taken my medicine for today.

original: Appevanāma svepi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāyā’ti.
analyzed: sve pi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāya ati
translated: Perhaps we could visit him tomorrow, if there is time.’

original: Ettāvatāpi kho, bho, katameva etaṁ, yato kho so bhavaṁ ānando okāsamakāsi svātanāyapi upasaṅkamanāyā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā api kho bho katamā iva yatas kho saḥ bhavam ānandaḥ upasaṅkamanāya ati
translated: “‘To that extent, sir, it is settled that the venerable Ānanda has given us a chance to see him.’

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ tassāḥ rattiyāḥ accayena pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya
translated: “Then, when the night had past, the venerable Ānanda, having put on his robes in the morning and taking his bowl and outer robe,

analyzed: cetakena bhikkhunā pacchāsamaṇena yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyya puttassa nivesana
translated: went with the venerable Cetiya as his attendant to the house of Subha the son of Todeyya,

analyzed: tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi atha kho subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya putto
translated: sat down on the seat made ready, and Subha the son of Todeyya

analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho subhaḥ māṇavaḥ todeyya puttaḥ āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: and after a courteous and amiable talk, sat down at one side. Subha the son of Todeyya said to the venerable Ānanda:

original: “bhavañhi ānando tassa bhoto gotamassa dīgharattaṁ upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaro samīpacārī.🔽Bhavametaṁ ānando jāneyya, yesaṁ so bhavaṁ gotamo dhammānaṁ vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: bhavan hi ānandaḥ tassa bhoto gotamassa dīgharattam upaṭṭhākaḥ santika avacaraḥ samīpa cārī  bhavam etam ānandaḥ jāneyya yesam saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ dhammānam vaṇṇa vādī ahosi yattha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: “Master Ānanda has long been the attendant of Master Gotama, he has long been in charge of his affairs.🔽Master Ānanda would know whether Master Gotama praised and recommended these things.”

original: Katamesānaṁ kho, bho ānanda, dhammānaṁ so bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi; kattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?🔽“Tiṇṇaṁ kho, māṇava, khandhānaṁ so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi; ettha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.🔽Katamesaṁ tiṇṇaṁ?
analyzed: katamesānam kho bho ānanda dhammānam saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ vaṇṇa vādī ahosi kattha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi iti  tiṇṇam kho māṇava khandhānam so bhagavā vaṇṇa vādī ahosi ettha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi  katamesam
translated: “What things did Master Gotama praise and recommend?”

original: Ariyassa sīlakkhandhassa, ariyassa samādhikkhandhassa, ariyassa paññākkhandhassa.
analyzed: ariyassa sīla kkhandhassa ariyassa samādhi kkhandhassa ariyassa paññā kkhandhassa
translated: “The three aggregates of virtuous behavior, concentration, and wisdom.

original: Imesaṁ kho, māṇava, tiṇṇaṁ khandhānaṁ so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi; ettha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti.
analyzed: imesam kho māṇava tiṇṇam khandhānam so bhagavā vaṇṇa vādī ahosi ettha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi iti
translated: These are the things that Master Gotama praised and recommended.”

original: 1. Sīlakkhandha
analyzed: sīlakkhandha
translated: 1. The aggregate of virtue

original: “Katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho, yassa so bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?🔽“Idha, māṇava, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
analyzed: katamaḥ pana saḥ bho ānanda ariyaḥ sīla kkhandho yassa saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ vaṇṇa vādī ahosi yattha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi iti  idha māṇava tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā
translated: “But, Master Ananda, what is this noble aggregate of virtue of which the Reverend Gotama spoke in such a way as to show that it was dependent on the higher ideal?”🔽“Here, student, a Tathagata appears in the world, accomplished, fully enlightened …

original: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
analyzed: saḥ imam lokam sa devakam sa mārakam sa brahmakam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇim pajam sa deva manussam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti
translated: He reveals this world—with its devas, Mara, and Brahma, this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and hum ans—having himself realized it through direct knowledge.

original: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
analyzed: saḥ dhammam deseti ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāseti
translated: He teaches the Dhamma good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.

original: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
analyzed: tam dhammam suṇāti gahapati vā gahapati putto vā aññatarasmim vā kule paccājātaḥ
translated: A householder or householder’s son or one born in some other clan hears that Dhamma.

original: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: saḥ tam dhammam sutvā tathāgate saddham paṭilabhati
translated: Having heard that Dhamma, he acquires faith in the Tathāgata.

original: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ tena saddhā paṭilābhena samannāgataḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: Endowed with that faith, he considers thus:

original: ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā,🔽nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
analyzed: sambādhaḥ gharāvāsaḥ rajopathaḥ abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā  na idam sukaram agāram ajjhāvasatā ekanta paripuṇṇam ekanta parisuddham saṅkha likhitam brahmacariyam caritu
translated: ‘Household life is crowded and dusty; life gone forth is wide open.🔽It is not easy, while living in a home, to lead the holy life utterly perfect and pure as a polished shell.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham kesa massuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti
translated: Suppose I shave off my hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness.’

original: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya🔽appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā
analyzed: so aparena samayena appam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya mahantam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya  appam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya mahantam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya kesa massuṃ ohāretvā
translated: “Then, after some time, he abandons a small or large fortune, abandons a small or large circle of relatives,

original: kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
analyzed: kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajati
translated: shaves off his hair and beard, puts on the yellow robe, and goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati, ācāragocarasampanno,
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ pātimokkha savara savutaḥ viharati ācāra gocara sampannaḥ
translated: Having thus gone forth, he dwells restrained by the Pātimokkha, and is endowed with good conduct and resort,

original: anumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena
analyzed: anumattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu kāya kamma vacī kammena
translated: seeing fear in faults that are blameworthy even though slight, trains in the precepts he has undertaken, and is endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal actions.

original: samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo, sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena
analyzed: samannāgataḥ kusalena parisuddha ājīvaḥ sīla sampanno indriyesu gutta dvāro sati sampajaññena
translated: He is pure in livelihood, perfected in morality, guarded in the senses,

original: samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ santuṭṭhaḥ
translated: mindful and clearly comprehending, and contented.

original: Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti?🔽Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
analyzed: kathañca māṇava bhikkhu sīla sampannaḥ hoti  idha māṇava bhikkhu pāṇa atipātam pahāya pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti nihita daṇḍaḥ nihita satthaḥ lajjī dayā āpannaḥ sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī viharati
translated: “And how, young man, is a monastic perfected in morality?🔽Here, young man, a monastic, having abandoned the killing of living beings, dwells refraining from the killing of living beings, without stick-borne or weapon-borne, scrupulous, compassionate, trembling for the welfare of all living beings.

original: Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati;
analyzed: yam pi māṇava bhikkhu pāṇa atipātam pahāya pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti nihita daṇḍaḥ nihita satthaḥ lajjī dayā āpannaḥ sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī viharati
translated: In that a monastic, having abandoned the killing of living beings, dwells refraining from the killing of living beings, without stick-borne or weapon-borne, scrupulous, compassionate, trembling for the welfare of all living beings,

original: idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti sīlasmi
translated: this is said to be his morality.

translated: As some worthy ascetics and brahmins, after eating food given by the faithful,

original: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchāna vijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: He abstains from such wrong livelihood.

original: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti sīlasmi
translated: This is his virtue.

original: Sa kho so, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṁ samanupassati, yadidaṁ sīlasaṁvarato.
analyzed: sa kho saḥ māṇava bhikkhu evam sīla sampannaḥ na kutocid bhayam samanupassati yat idam sīla savarato
translated: “When a bhikkhu is virtuous, possessing this kind of virtue, he does not see any danger anywhere from fear of violation of virtue.

original: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto nihatapaccāmitto na kutoci bhayaṁ samanupassati, yadidaṁ paccatthikato;
analyzed: seyyathā api māṇava rājā khattiyaḥ muddhāvasittaḥ nihata paccāmittaḥ na kutoci bhayam samanupassati yat idam paccatthikato
translated: Just as a head-anointed noble king, having defeated his enemies, does not see any danger anywhere from fear of enemies,

original: evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṁ samanupassati, yadidaṁ sīlasaṁvarato.
analyzed: evam eva kho māṇava bhikkhu evam sīla sampannaḥ na kutocid bhayam samanupassati yat idam sīla savarato
translated: so too a bhikkhu…does not see any danger anywhere from fear of violation of virtue.

original: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: saḥ iminā ariyena sīla kkhandhena samannāgataḥ ajjhattam anavajja sukham paṭisavedeti
translated: Possessing this aggregate of noble virtue, he experiences within himself a bliss that is blameless.

original: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti.
analyzed: evam kho māṇava bhikkhu sīla sampannaḥ hoti
translated: This is how a bhikkhu is virtuous.

original: Ayaṁ kho so, māṇava, ariyo sīlakkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: ayam kho saḥ māṇava ariyaḥ sīla kkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇa vādī ahosi yattha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: This, student, is that aggregate of noble virtue of which the Blessed One spoke. And he exhorts, rouses, enthuses, and encourages his disciples with Dhamma talks referring to this virtue.

original: Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan”ti.
analyzed: atthi ca iva itthā uttari karaṇīyanti
translated: But there is still more to be done.”

original: “Acchariyaṁ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṁ, bho ānanda.
analyzed: acchariya bho ānanda abbhuta bho ānanda
translated: “It’s astounding and amazing, Master Ānanda,

original: So cāyaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo.
analyzed: so ca aya bho ānanda ariyaḥ sīlakkhandho paripuṇṇaḥ no a paripuṇṇaḥ
translated: that this aggregate of noble virtue is fulfilled, not unfulfilled.

original: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañcāhaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ sīlakkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi.
analyzed: evam paripuṇṇam ca āha bho ānanda ariyam sīla kkhandham itas bahiddhā aññesu samaṇa brāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi
translated: And I don’t see this aggregate of noble virtue fulfilled like this in any of the ascetics and brahmins of other schools.

original: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañca, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ sīlakkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇā attani samanupasseyyuṁ, te tāvatakeneva attamanā assu:
analyzed: evam paripuṇṇam ca bho ānanda ariyam sīla kkhandham itas bahiddhā aññe samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ attani samanupasseyyu te tāvatakena iva attamanāḥ assu
translated: If those ascetics and brahmins of other schools were to see this aggregate of noble virtue fulfilled in themselves, they would be satisfied and delighted, thinking:

original: ‘alamettāvatā, katamettāvatā, anuppatto no sāmaññattho, natthi no kiñci uttarikaraṇīyan’ti.
analyzed: alam ettāvatā katamā ittāvatā anuppattaḥ no sāmaññattho natthi no kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti
translated: ‘We have enough! We have done enough! We have achieved what needs to be achieved! There is nothing more for us to do!’

original: Atha ca pana bhavaṁ ānando evamāha:
analyzed: atha ca pana bhavam ānandaḥ evam āha
translated: And yet Master Ānanda says:

original: ‘atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan’”ti.
analyzed: atthi ca iva itthā uttari karaṇīyanti
translated: ‘But there is still more to be done.’”

original: 2. Samādhikkhandha
analyzed: samādhi kkhandha
translated: The aggregate of concentration

original: “Katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo samādhikkhandho, yassa so bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?
analyzed: katamaḥ pana saḥ bho ānanda ariyaḥ samādhi khandho yassa saḥ bhavam gotamaḥ vaṇṇa vādī ahosi yattha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi iti
translated: “But, Master Ananda, what is that noble concentration of the heart that the Blessed One praised?”

original: “Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
analyzed: kathañca māṇava bhikkhu indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ hoti
translated: “And how, student, does a bhikkhu guard the doors of his sense faculties?

original: Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;🔽yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: idha māṇava bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī  yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: On seeing a form with the eye, a bhikkhu does not grasp at its signs and features.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ; tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati cakkhu indriya cakkhu indriye savaram āpajjati
translated: Since, if he left the eye faculty unguarded, bad, unwholesome states of longing and dejection might invade him, he practices guarding it, he protects the eye faculty, he achieves restraint over it.

original: Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …pe…🔽ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …
analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā pe  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā
translated: On hearing a sound with the ear…🔽On smelling an odour with the nose…

original: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: On tasting a flavour with the tongue…

original: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: On touching a tangible with the body…

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī
translated: On cognizing a mind-object with the mind, a bhikkhu does not grasp at its signs and features.

original: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam man indriyam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: If the faculty of the mind is left unrestrained, evil unwholesome states of covetousness and grief might invade him.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ; tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati manindriya manindriye savaram āpajjati
translated: He practices for the restraint of the faculty of the mind, he guards the faculty of the mind, he achieves restraint over the faculty of the mind.

original: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: saḥ iminā ariyena indriya savarena samannāgataḥ ajjhattam a byāseka sukham paṭisaveda iti
translated: Endowed with this noble restraint of the faculties, he experiences within himself a bliss that is blameless.

original: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
analyzed: evam kho māṇava bhikkhu indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ hoti
translated: It is in such a way, student, that a bhikkhu guards the doors of his faculties.

original: Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti?🔽Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite🔽sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe
analyzed: kathañca māṇava bhikkhu sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ hoti  idha māṇava bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti ālokite vilokite  sampajāna kārī hoti samiñjite pasārite sampajāna kārī hoti saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe
translated: “And how, student, is a bhikkhu consummate in mindfulness and clear awareness?

original: sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajāna kārī hoti uccāra passāva kamme
translated: Here, student, a bhikkhu acts with clear awareness in going forth and back, in looking ahead and looking aside, in drawing in and extending the limbs, in wearing the shoulder-cloak, the robes, and the bowl, in eating, in drinking, in chewing, in tasting, in evacuating bowels and voiding urine, in walking, in standing, in sitting, in sleeping, in waking, in talking, and in maintaining silence.

original: sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī hoti
translated: he is clearly aware of it. Whether he is walking, standing, sitting or lying down, as long as he is awake, he is clearly aware of what he is doing.

original: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti.
analyzed: evam kho māṇava bhikkhu sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ hoti
translated: It is in such a way, student, that a bhikkhu possesses full awareness and clear comprehension.

original: Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti?
analyzed: kathañca māṇava bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: “And how, student, is a bhikkhu content?🔽Here, student, a bhikkhu is content with robes to protect his body and almsfood to sustain his belly.

original: Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
analyzed: idha māṇava bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti kāya parihārikena cīvarena kucchi parihārikena piṇḍapātena saḥ yena yena iva pakkamati samādāya iva pakkamati
translated: Wherever he goes, he takes only these with him,

original: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti, sapattabhārova ḍeti;
analyzed: seyyathā api māṇava pakkhī sakuṇaḥ yena yena iva ḍeti sa patta bhāraḥ uva ḍeti
translated: just as a bird, wherever it flies, only takes its wings with it.

original: evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
analyzed: evam eva kho māṇava bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti kāya parihārikena cīvarena kucchi parihārikena piṇḍapātena saḥ yena yena iva pakkamati samādāya iva pakkamati
translated: So too, a bhikkhu is content with robes to protect his body and almsfood to sustain his belly. Wherever he goes, he takes only these with him.

original: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti.
analyzed: evam kho māṇava bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: It is in such a way, student, that a bhikkhu is content.

original: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena
analyzed: saḥ iminā ca ariyena sīla kkhandhena samannāgataḥ iminā ca ariyena indriya savarena
translated: Possessing this aggregate of noble virtue,

original: samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato
analyzed: samannāgataḥ iminā ca ariyena sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgataḥ
translated: and with this noble restraint of the faculties, and with this noble contentment,

original: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
analyzed: vivittam senāsanam bhajati araññam rukkha mūlam pabbatam kandaram giri guham su sānam vana pattham abbhokāsam palāla puñja
translated: he frequents a secluded lodging, a forest, the foot of a tree, a mountain, a ravine, a hillside cave, a charnel ground, a jungle thicket, an open space, a heap of straw.

original: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā, ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: saḥ pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: After his meal, on his return from alms round, he sits down, crosses his legs, holds his body erect, and brings mindfulness to the fore.

original: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: saḥ abhijjham loke pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up longing for the world, and abides with a mind free from longing; he purifies his mind of longing.

original: Byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: byāpāda padosam pahāya a byāpanna cittaḥ viharati sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī byāpāda padosā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up ill will and malevolence, and abides with a mind free from ill will, compassionate for the welfare of all living beings; he purifies his mind of ill will.

original: Thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: thinamiddham pahāya vigata thinamiddhaḥ viharati āloka saññī sataḥ sampajānaḥ thinamiddhā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up dullness and drowsiness, and abides free from dullness and drowsiness, percipient of light, mindful and clearly comprehending; he purifies his mind of dullness and drowsiness.

original: Uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam pahāya anuddhataḥ viharati ajjhattam vūpasanta cittaḥ uddhacca kukkuccā cittam parisodheti
translated: He abandons restlessness and dwells without it, inwardly peaceful, with a stilled mind, having abandoned restlessness.

original: Vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: vicikiccham pahāya tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ viharati a kathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu vicikicchāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He abandons doubt and dwells without it, having crossed over doubt about wholesome qualities, his mind purified of doubt.

original: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojeyya.
analyzed: sa iyyathā api māṇava purisaḥ iṇam ādāya kammante payojeyya
translated: “Suppose a man took out a loan and undertook business.

original: Tassa te kammantā samijjheyyuṁ.
analyzed: tassa te kammantā samijjheyyu
translated: His business succeeded.

original: So yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantiṁ kareyya, siyā cassa uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāya.
analyzed: saḥ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇa mūlāni tāni ca byantim kareyya siyā ca assa uttarim avasiṭṭham dāra bharaṇāya
translated: He paid off his old debts and had some surplus left over for his wife and children.

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: He might think:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojesiṁ.
analyzed: aham kho pubbe iṇam ādāya kammante payojesi
translated: ‘In the past I took out a loan and undertook business.

original: Tassa me te kammantā samijjhiṁsu.
analyzed: tassa me te kammantā samijjhisu
translated: My business succeeded.

original: Sohaṁ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantiṁ akāsiṁ, atthi ca me uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāyā’ti.
analyzed: saḥ ham yāni ca porāṇāni iṇa mūlāni tāni ca akāsi atthi ca me uttarim avasiṭṭham dāra bharaṇāya ati
translated: I paid off my old debts and have a surplus left over for my wife and children.’

original: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tatonidānam labhetha pāmojja adhigaccheyya somanassa
translated: Because of that he would experience joy and gladness.

translated: ‘Formerly I was a man with possessions and property, travelling along the desert highway, which is a place of affliction and danger.

original: Somhi etarahi taṁ kantāraṁ nitthiṇṇo, sotthinā gāmantaṁ anuppatto khemaṁ appaṭibhayan’ti.

translated: So too, student, a bhikkhu sees that these five hindrances have not been abandoned in himself.

original: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, yathā āṇaṇyaṁ yathā ārogyaṁ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṁ yathā bhujissaṁ yathā khemantabhūmiṁ.
analyzed: sā iyyathā api māṇava yathā āṇaṇyam yathā ārogyam yathā bandha nāmokkham yathā bhujissam yathā khemanta bhūmi
translated: Just as a man in debt, who is sick, imprisoned, in slavery, travelling along a desert highway, would feel joy and gladness on seeing his own native land;

original: Evameva kho bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati.
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati
translated: so too, a bhikkhu sees that these five hindrances have been abandoned in himself.

original: Tassime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: tassa ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: When he sees these five hindrances abandoned within himself, joy arises in him; joy being present, rapture arises; when the mind is uplifted by rapture, the body becomes tranquil; one tranquil in body experiences happiness; and the mind of one who is happy becomes concentrated.🔽Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, he enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and happiness born of seclusion.🔽He permeates and pervades, suffuses and fills this very body with the happiness and joy born of seclusion.

original: So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.

translated: So imameva kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti |

translated: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṁsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni ākiritvā

original: ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṁ paripphosakaṁ sanneyya. Sāyaṁ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā
analyzed: ākiritvā udakena paripphosakam paripphosakam sanneyya sāyam nhānīya piṇḍi sneha anugatā
translated: udakena paripphosakaṃ paripphosakaṃ sanneyya |

translated: “So too, student, a bhikkhu makes the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body that is not pervaded by the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

translated: So too, a bhikkhu makes the pleasure divested of rapture drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the pleasure divested of rapture.

original: Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.

translated: “Again, a bhikkhu, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief, enters and dwells in the fourth jhana, neither painful nor pleasant, which has purification of mindfulness by equanimity.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.

translated: So he makes the pleasure divested of rapture drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the pleasure divested of rapture.

translated: This is his mastery of concentration.

translated: This is his equanimity in the sense of non-excess.🔽“Again, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ
analyzed: puna capara māṇava bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassāna
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu, having abandoned pleasure and pain, and with the disappearance of former gladness and sadness, enters and dwells in the fourth jhāna that has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness.

original: atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽So imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti;
analyzed: atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati  saḥ imam eva kāyam parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena nisinnaḥ hoti
translated: “Again, bhikkhus, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous passing away of joy and dejection, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭam hoti
translated: “He sits pervading this body with pure bright mind so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by pure bright mind.

original: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṁ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṁ assa.🔽Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
analyzed: seyyathā api māṇava purisaḥ odātena vatthena sa sīsam pārupitvā nisinnaḥ assa na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭam assa  evam eva kho māṇava bhikkhu pe
translated: Just as though a man were sitting covered from the head down with a white cloth, so that there would be no part of his whole body not covered by the white cloth;🔽so too, a bhikkhu sits pervading this body with pure bright mind so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by pure bright mind.

original: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: yam pi māṇava bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassānam atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “This, bhikkhus, is a field of deliverance for one who has not been delivered.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinnaḥ hoti na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭam hoti
translated: He sits pervading this very body with a pure bright mind, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the pure bright mind.

original: Idampissa hoti samādhismiṁ.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti samādhismi
translated: This is the second factor of his.

original: Ayaṁ kho so, māṇava, ariyo samādhikkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: ayam kho saḥ māṇava ariyaḥ samādhi khandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇa vādī ahosi yattha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: This, student, is that noble concentration of mind by means of which, when he dwells in the attainment of concentration, the Tathāgata, with the destruction of the taints, directly experiences for himself with equanimity.

original: Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan”ti.
analyzed: atthi ca iva itthā uttari karaṇīyanti
translated: And there is more to be done.”

original: “Acchariyaṁ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṁ, bho ānanda.
analyzed: acchariya bho ānanda abbhuta bho ānanda
translated: “It is wonderful, Master Ananda, it is marvellous!

original: So cāyaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyo samādhikkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo.
analyzed: so ca aya bho ānanda ariyaḥ samādhi khandho paripuṇṇaḥ no a paripuṇṇaḥ
translated: And this noble concentration of mind is fulfilled, not unfulfilled.

original: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañcāhaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ samādhikkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi.
analyzed: evam paripuṇṇam ca āha bho ānanda ariyam samādhi khandham itas bahiddhā aññesu samaṇa brāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi
translated: And I do not see that concentration of mind fulfilled thus even among the ascetics and brahmins of other sects.

original: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañca, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ samādhikkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇā attani samanupasseyyuṁ, te tāvatakeneva attamanā assu:
analyzed: evam paripuṇṇam ca bho ānanda ariyam samādhi kkhandham itas bahiddhā aññe samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ attani samanupasseyyu te tāvatakena iva attamanāḥ assu
translated: If other ascetics and Brahmins were to find such a perfect concentration-aggregate in themselves, they would think:

original: ‘alamettāvatā, katamettāvatā, anuppatto no sāmaññattho, natthi no kiñci uttarikaraṇīyan’ti.
analyzed: alam ettāvatā katamā ittāvatā anuppattaḥ no sāmaññattho natthi no kiñci uttari karaṇīyanti
translated: ‘We have attained the goal of the holy life, there is nothing more for us to do!’

original: Atha ca pana bhavaṁ ānando evamāha:
analyzed: atha ca pana bhavam ānandaḥ evam āha
translated: And yet the Venerable Ananda says:

original: ‘atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan’ti.
analyzed: atthi ca iva itthā uttari karaṇīyanti
translated: ‘There is more to be done!’

original: 3. Paññākkhandha

original: Katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo paññākkhandho, yassa bho bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?

translated: But what, Reverend Ananda, is that noble wisdom-aggregate which the Reverend Gotama praised? ”

original: “So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.

translated: “When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, free of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the corruptions.

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:

original: ‘ayaṁ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṁsanadhammo;

translated: ‘This body of mine is material, made up of the four great elements, procreated by mother and father, built up out of boiled rice and porridge, and subject to impermanence, to being worn and rubbed away, to dissolution and disintegration,🔽

It is subject to impermanence, to being worn and rubbed away, to dissolution and disintegration, and this consciousness of mine is supported by it and bound up with it.’

original: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno🔽anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatrāssa suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā.🔽Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya: ‘ayaṁ kho maṇi veḷuriyo subho
analyzed: seyyathā api māṇava maṇi veḷuriyaḥ subhaḥ jātimā aṭṭhasas su parikamma kataḥ acchassa vippasanno  anāvilaḥ sabba ākāra sampanno tatra assa suttam āvutam nīlam vā pītam vā lohitam vā odātam vā paṇḍu suttam vā  tam enam cakkhumā purisaḥ hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya ayam kho maṇi veḷuriyaḥ subho
translated: Just as if there were a gem, a beryl, pure, excellent, well cut, of eight facets, clear, bright, unflawed, perfect in every respect,

original: jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatridaṁ
analyzed: jātimā aṭṭhasas su parikamma kataḥ acchaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ sabba ākāra sampanno tatrida
translated: and a man with good eyesight, taking it in his hand, were to reflect on it thus: ‘This gem, a beryl, is pure, excellent, well cut, of eight facets, clear, bright, unflawed, perfect in every respect.

original: suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā’ti.
analyzed: suttam āvutam nīlam vā pītam vā lohitam vā odātam vā paṇḍusuttam vā ati
translated: And this thread is twisted round it, blue, yellow, red, white, or brown.’🔽So too, a bhikkhu reflects thus: ‘This body of mine is material, made up of the four great elements, procreated by a mother and father, and built up out of boiled rice and porridge. It is subject to impermanence, to being worn and rubbed away, to dissolution and disintegration, and this consciousness of mine is supported by it and bound up with it.’

translated: This is the second knowledge attained by him.🔽“Again, when a bhikkhu’s mind is concentrated…

The sheath is one, the reed is another; it is the reed that has been pulled out from the sheath,’

translated: so too, he creates from this body another body, possessed of form, mind-made, complete in all its parts, not lacking any faculties.

translated: “Just as if a man were to pull a sword out of its scabbard and think, ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard. translated: “Just as if a man were to pull a snake out from its slough and think, ‘This is the snake, this is the slough. The snake is one, the slough is another; it is the snake that has been pulled out from the slough,’

translated: ‘This is the snake, this is the pot. The snake is one thing, the pot is another.’

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte iddhividhāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.🔽So anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte iddhi vidhāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti  saḥ aneka vihitam iddhi vidham paccanubhoti ekaḥ api hutvā bahudhā hoti bahudhā api hutvā
translated: “When his concentrated mind is purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to the modes of supernormal power.

original: eko hoti; āvibhāvaṁ tirobhāvaṁ tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ asajjamāno gacchati
analyzed: ekaḥ hoti āvi bhāvam tirobhāvam tiro kuṭṭam tiro pākāram tiro pabbatam a sajjamānaḥ gacchati
translated: He wields the various kinds of supernormal power: having been one, he becomes many; having been many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through a wall, through a rampart, through a mountain as though through space;🔽he dives in and out of the earth as though through water; he goes on unbroken water as though on earth; seated cross-legged he travels through space like a bird; with his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; he wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā world.

original: seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karoti seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne
analyzed: seyyathā api ākāse pathaviyā api ummujja nimujjam karoti seyyathā api udake udake api abhijjamāne
translated: He dives in and out of the earth as if it were water.🔽He walks on water without sinking as if it were dry land.

original: gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo;🔽imepi candimasūriye evaṁ mahiddhike evaṁ mahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati;
analyzed: gacchati seyyathā api pathaviye ākāse pi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇaḥ  ime api candima sūriye evam mahiddhike evam mahā anubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati
translated: Seated cross-legged he flies through the air like a winged bird.

original: yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti.
analyzed: yāva brahma lokā api kāyena vasam vatta iti
translated: With his hand he touches and strokes even Brahmā’s world.🔽Just as a strong man might stretch out his bent arm or bend his outstretched arm, so does he, being one, arise in many forms, and being many, re-arise as one.🔽With his divine ear, purified and surpassing that of men, he hears both kinds of sounds, divine and human, whether near or far.🔽He understands how beings fare in accordance with their kamma: ‘These worthy beings who were ill-conducted in body, speech, and mind, revilers of noble ones, wrong in their views, giving effect to wrong view in their actions, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a state of deprivation, in a bad destination, in perdition, even in hell;🔽but these worthy beings who were well-conducted in body, speech, and mind, not revilers of noble ones, right in their views, giving effect to right view in their actions, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a good destination, even in the heavenly world.’ Thus with his mind, thus purified and cleansed, he directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽Just as a skilled potter or his apprentice might make or fashion out of well-prepared clay any kind of vessel he wished;🔽or as a skilled ivory-worker or his apprentice might make or fashion out of well-prepared ivory any kind of ivory work he wished;

original: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, dakkho kumbhakāro vā kumbhakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatāya mattikāya yaññadeva bhājanavikatiṁ ākaṅkheyya, taṁ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya.🔽Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, dakkho dantakāro vā dantakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatasmiṁ dantasmiṁ yaññadeva dantavikatiṁ ākaṅkheyya, taṁ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya.
analyzed: seyyathā api māṇava dakkhaḥ kumbhakāraḥ vā kumbhakāra antevāsī vā su parikammakatāya mattikāya yaññat eva bhājana vikatim ākaṅkheyya tam tat eva kareyya abhinipphādeyya 🔽seyyathā vā pana māṇava dakkhaḥ dantakāraḥ vā dantakāra antevāsī vā su parikamma katasmim dantasmim yaññat eva danta vikatim ākaṅkheyya tam tat eva kareyya abhinipphādeyya
translated: or as a skilled goldsmith or his apprentice might make or fashion out of well-prepared gold any kind of gold article he wished;

original: Idampissa hoti paññāya.

translated: after the break-up of the body, after death, have arisen in a bad destination, a bad place, a world below, hell.

original: sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā🔽ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ🔽maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena
analyzed: sattā kāya su caritena samannāgatā vacī su caritena samannāgatā manaḥ su caritena samannāgatā  ariyānaṃ an upavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa bhedā para  maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ati iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena
translated: But these worthy beings who were well-conducted in body, speech, and mind, not revilers of Noble Ones, right in their views, who undertook actions right in their view,🔽after the break-up of the body, after death, have arisen in a good destination, a heavenly world.’ Thus with his mind, which is purified and cleansed, and has become sensitive, supple, workable, firm, and unperturbed,🔽he directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the destruction of the pollutants.

original: satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate,
analyzed: satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate
translated: He knows as it really is: ‘This is suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the practice leading to the cessation of suffering’.🔽He knows as it really is: ‘These are the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the practice leading to the cessation of the pollutants’.

original: yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.🔽Seyyathāpi, māṇava, majjhesiṅghāṭake pāsādo, tattha cakkhumā puriso ṭhito passeyya
analyzed: yathā kammūpage satte pajānāti  seyyathā api māṇava majjhesiṅghāṭake pāsādaḥ tattha cakkhumā puriso ṭhito passeyya
translated: he knows beings passing away and arising.

original: manusse gehaṁ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikāyapi vīthiṁ sañcarante majjhesiṅghāṭake🔽nisinnepi. Tassa evamassa: ‘ete manussā gehaṁ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikāya
analyzed: manusse geham pavisante api nikkhamante api rathikāya api vīthim sañcarante majjhesiṅghāṭake  nisinne pi tassa evam assa ete manussāḥ geham pavisanti ete nikkhamanti ete rathikāya
translated: “Suppose, student, there was a tall building at a crossroads, and a man with good eyesight standing there might see people entering and leaving a house, walking in the street, and sitting in the middle of the crossroads.

original: vīthiṁ sañcaranti, ete majjhesiṅghāṭake nisinnā’ti.
analyzed: vīthim sañcaranti ete majjhesiṅghāṭake nisinnā ati
translated: The thought would occur to him: ‘These people are entering a house, these are leaving a house, these are walking in the street, these are sitting in the middle of the crossroads.’

original: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
analyzed: evam eva kho māṇava bhikkhu pe
translated: In the same way, a bhikkhu …

original: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: yam pi māṇava bhikkhu evam samāhite citte pe āneñja ppatte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāmeti
translated: concentrates his mind … and directs it to the knowledge of the passing away and arising of beings.

original: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathā kammūpage satte pajānāti
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and arising: base and noble, well favo-red and ill-favored, to happy and unhappy destinations as kamma directs them. He understands how beings pass on according to their kamma.

original: Idampissa hoti paññāya.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti paññāya
translated: This is the second knowledge attained by him, and this knowledge is due to his wisdom.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti
translated: When his concentrated mind was purified, bright, unblemished, free from imperfection, malleable, workable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directed it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understood as it really is: “This is suffering”; he understood as it really is: “This is the origin of suffering”;

original: ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodhaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understood as it really is: “This is the cessation of suffering”; he understood as it really is: “This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering”;🔽he understood as it really is: “These are the taints”; he understood as it really is: “This is the origin of the taints”;

original: ime āsavāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ime āsavā ati yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodhaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understood as it really is: “This is the cessation of the taints”; he understood as it really is: “This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.”

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati,
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knew and saw thus, his mind was liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it was liberated there came the knowledge: “It is liberated.”🔽He directly knew: “Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.”

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.🔽Seyyathāpi, māṇava, pabbatasaṅkhepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo. Tattha
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti  seyyathā api māṇava pabbata saṅkhepe udaka rahadaḥ acchaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ tattha
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’🔽“Suppose, student, there was a pond in a mountain recess, clear, limpid, and undisturbed,

original: cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi
analyzed: cakkhumā purisaḥ tīre ṭhito passeyya sippi sambukam pi sakkharakathalam pi maccha gumbam pi
translated: so that a man with good eyesight standing on the bank could see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.

original: carantampi tiṭṭhantampi. Tassa evamassa: ‘ayaṁ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo.
analyzed: carantam pi tiṭṭhantam pi tassa evam assa ayam kho udaka rahadaḥ acchaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ
translated: He might think: ‘This pond is clear, limpid, and undisturbed,

original: Tatrime sippisambukāpi sakkharakathalāpi macchagumbāpi carantipi tiṭṭhantipī’ti.
analyzed: tatra ime sippi sambukāḥ api sakkhara kathalāḥ api maccha gumbāḥ caranti pi tiṭṭhanti pi iti
translated: so that I can see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.’

original: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
analyzed: evam eva kho māṇava bhikkhu pe
translated: So too, student, a bhikkhu…

original: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: yam pi māṇava bhikkhu evam samāhite citte pe āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāmeti
translated: “When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe…
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam pajānāti pe
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’;…

original: āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’🔽“He understands: ‘Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati,🔽avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti, ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati  cittam vimuccati vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance. When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’ He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance. When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’ He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Idampissa hoti paññāya.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti paññāya
translated: This is his wisdom.

original: Ayaṁ kho so, māṇava, ariyo paññākkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
analyzed: ayam kho saḥ māṇava ariyaḥ paññākkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇa vādī ahosi yattha ca imam janatam samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: This, student, is that noble wisdom of whose praise I was aware when I said that there was.

original: Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan”ti.
analyzed: natthi ca iva itthā uttari karaṇīyanti
translated: There is nothing further to be done.”

original: “Acchariyaṁ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṁ, bho ānanda.
analyzed: acchariya bho ānanda abbhuta bho ānanda
translated: “It is wonderful, Master Ananda, it is marvellous!

original: So cāyaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyo paññākkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo.
analyzed: so ca aya bho ānanda ariyaḥ paññākkhandho paripuṇṇaḥ no a paripuṇṇaḥ
translated: This noble wisdom is complete, not incomplete.

original: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañcāhaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ paññākkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi.
analyzed: evam paripuṇṇam ca āha bho ānanda ariyam paññā kkhandham itas bahiddhā aññesu samaṇa brāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi
translated: I do not see any other noble wisdom apart from this that is complete, not incomplete.

original: Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyaṁ.
analyzed: natthi ca iva ittha uttari karaṇīya
translated: There is nothing further to be done.

original: Abhikkantaṁ, bho ānanda, abhikkantaṁ, bho ānanda.🔽Seyyathāpi, bho ānanda, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa
analyzed: abhikkanta bho ānanda abhikkanta bho ānanda  sā iyyathā api bho ānanda nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa
translated: Excellent, Master Ananda, excellent!

original: vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: Just as if he were to place upright what was overturned, to reveal what was hidden, to show the way to one who was lost, or to carry a lamp into the dark so that those with eyes could see forms,

original: evamevaṁ bhotā ānandena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: evam evam bhotā ānandena aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: in the same way has Master Ananda — through many lines of reasoning — made the Dhamma clear.

original: Esāhaṁ, bho ānanda, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
analyzed: esā aha bho ānanda tam bhavantam gotamam saraṇam gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: I go to Master Gotama for refuge, to the Dhamma, and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ ānando dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.
analyzed: upāsakam mam bhavan ānandaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetam saraṇam gatanti
translated: May Master Ananda remember me as a lay follower who has gone to him for refuge, from this day forward, for life.”

original: Subhasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ dasamaṁ.
analyzed: subha suttam niṭṭhitam dasama
translated: The tenth sutta in the Sutta Nipata
